questions.stem:
Refer to the drawing of a section of 6-inch diameter pipe containing subcooled water flowing from
left to right at 100 gpm (see figure below).
The pipe is frictionless and no heat transfer is occurring. Point B is 10 feet higher in elevation than
point A.
How does the enthalpy of the water at point A compare to point B?
choices: A. The enthalpy of the water at point A is smaller, because some of the water’s kinetic energy is
B. The enthalpy of the water at point A is greater, because some of the water’s enthalpy is
C. The enthalpy of the water at points A and B is the same, because the pipe is frictionless and no
D. The enthalpy of the water at points A and B is the same, because the total energy of the water

questions.stem:
For which of the following ideal processes, if any, is the fluid outlet enthalpy greater than the fluid
inlet enthalpy? (Assume horizontal fluid flow in each process.)
(A) Cooling water flowing through a fixed convergent nozzle.
(B) Cooling water flowing through an operating lube oil heat exchanger.
